wave</div>					<article id="article-content" class="content"><section id="ref1" data-level="1"><p><strong><span id="ref56143"></span>Tsunami</strong>, (Japanese: “harbour wave”)also called <strong>seismic sea wave </strong>or <strong>tidal wave</strong>,  catastrophic ocean <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/wave-physics" class="md-crosslink">wave</a>, usually caused by a submarine <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/earthquake-geology" class="md-crosslink">earthquake</a>, by an underwater or coastal <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/landslide" class="md-crosslink">landslide</a>, or by the eruption of a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/volcano" class="md-crosslink">volcano</a>. The term <em>tidal wave</em> is frequently used for such a wave, but it is a misnomer, for the wave has no connection with the tides.</p><!--[P1]--><ul class="assemblies medialist" data-type="other"><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="114382"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/25/118525-004-86CFA8D2.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/25/118525-004-86CFA8D2.jpg" alt="Aceh, Indonesia, tsunami" data-width="550" data-height="393"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">Aceh, Indonesia, tsunami</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">The aftermath of the December 2004 tsunami in Aceh, Indon.</span><cite>Philip A. McDaniel/U.S. Navy</cite></figcaption></figure></li><li><figure data-type="video" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="68438"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="video"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/92/73092-049-5509B8C7.jpg" alt="tsunami: 1946 Hilo tsunami" data-width="320" data-height="240"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">tsunami: 1946 Hilo tsunami</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">Vintage newsreels show the terrible destruction that a tsunami brought to Hilo, Hawaii, in 1946.</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></li></ul><!--[ML1]--></section><div class="major-reference-upsell">			<iframe src="/GPTIframe/ajax/sync/EB_HOUSE_DESKTOP" scrolling="no" width="640" height="106"></iframe>		</div><section id="ref299872" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">Origin and development</h2><p>After an earthquake or other generating impulse occurs, a train of simple, progressive oscillatory waves is <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/propagated" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="propagated">propagated</a> great distances over the ocean surface in ever-widening circles, much like the waves produced by a pebble falling into a shallow pool. In deep water a tsunami can travel as fast as 800 km (500 miles) per hour. The <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/wavelength" class="md-crosslink">wavelengths</a> are enormous, about 100 to 200 km (60 to 120 miles), but the wave amplitudes (heights) are very small, only about 30 to 60 cm (1 to 2 feet). The waves’ periods (the lengths of time for successive crests or troughs to pass a single point) are very long, varying from five minutes to more than an hour. These long periods, coupled with the extremely low steepness of the waves, enables them to be completely obscured in deep water by normal wind waves and swell. A ship on the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/high-seas" class="md-crosslink autoxref">high seas</a> experiences the passage of a tsunami as an insignificant rise and fall of only half a metre (1.6 feet), lasting from five minutes to an hour or more.</p><!--[P2]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="72285"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/87/177687-004-7536455F.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/87/177687-004-7536455F.jpg" alt="tsunami" data-width="485" data-height="400"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">tsunami</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">After being generated by an undersea earthquake or landslide, a tsunami may propagate unnoticed over vast reaches of open ocean before cresting in shallow water and inundating a coastline.</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML2]--><p>As the waves approach the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/coast" class="md-crosslink autoxref">coast</a> of a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/continent" class="md-crosslink autoxref">continent</a>, however, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/friction" class="md-crosslink">friction</a> with the rising sea bottom reduces the velocity of the waves. As the velocity lessens, the wavelengths become shortened and the wave amplitudes increase. Coastal waters may rise as high as 30 metres (about 100 feet) above normal <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/sea-level" class="md-crosslink">sea level</a> in 10 to 15 minutes. By a poorly understood process, the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/continental-shelf" class="md-crosslink autoxref">continental shelf</a> waters begin to oscillate after the rise in sea level. Between three and five major oscillations generate most of the damage, frequently appearing as powerful “run-ups” of rushing water that uproot trees, pull buildings off their foundations, carry boats far inshore, and wash away entire beaches, peninsulas, and other low-lying coastal formations. Frequently the succeeding outflow of water is just as destructive as the run-up or even more so. In any case, oscillations may continue for several days until the ocean surface reaches <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/equilibrium" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="equilibrium">equilibrium</a>.</p><!--[P3]--><p>Much like any other water waves, tsunamis are reflected and refracted by the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/topography" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="topography">topography</a> of the seafloor near shore and by the configuration of a coastline. As a result, their effects vary widely from place to place. Occasionally, the first arrival of a tsunami at a coast may be the trough of the wave, in which case the water recedes and exposes the shallow seafloor. Such an occurrence took place in the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/bay-coastal-feature" class="md-crosslink autoxref">bay</a> of <span id="ref56144"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Lisbon" class="md-crosslink">Lisbon</a>, Portugal, on November 1, 1755, after a large earthquake; many curious people were attracted to the bay floor, and a large number of them were drowned by the wave crest that followed the trough only minutes later (<em>see</em> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Lisbon-earthquake-of-1755" class="md-crosslink">Lisbon earthquake of 1755</a>).</p><!--[P4]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="video" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="165043"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="video"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/30/151930-049-99171DC8.jpg" alt="tsunami" data-width="320" data-height="240"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">tsunami</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">John Rafferty, associate editor of Earth sciences of <em>Encyclopædia Britannica</em>, discussing tsunamis.</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML4]--></section><!--[H3]--><section id="ref299873" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">Notable tsunamis</h2><p>One of the most-destructive <span id="ref1217511"></span>tsunamis in antiquity took place in the eastern <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Mediterranean-Sea" class="md-crosslink">Mediterranean Sea</a> on July 21, 365 <span class="text-smallcaps">ce</span>. A <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/fault-geology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">fault</a> slip in the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/subduction-zone" class="md-crosslink">subduction zone</a> beneath the island of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Crete" class="md-crosslink">Crete</a> produced an earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 8.0–8.5, which was powerful enough to raise parts of the western third of the island up to 10 metres (33 feet). The earthquake spawned a tsunami that claimed tens of thousands of lives and caused widespread damage throughout the Mediterranean from the coast of present-day Spain eastward. Tsunami waves pushed ships over <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/harbor" class="md-crosslink autoxref">harbour</a> walls and onto the roofs of houses in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Alexandria-Egypt" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Alexandria</a>, Egypt, while also ruining nearby croplands by inundating them with <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/seawater" class="md-crosslink autoxref">salt water</a>.</p><!--[P5]--><p>One of the most-destructive <span id="ref821129"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Indian-Ocean-tsunami-of-2004" class="md-crosslink">tsunamis</a> in recorded history took place on December 26, 2004, after an earthquake of magnitude 9.1 displaced the ocean floor off the Indonesian island of <span id="ref821130"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Sumatra" class="md-crosslink">Sumatra</a>. Two hours later, waves as high as 9 metres (30 feet) struck the eastern coasts of India and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Sri-Lanka" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Sri Lanka</a>, some 1,200 km (750 miles) away. Within seven hours of the quake, waves washed ashore on the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Horn-of-Africa" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Horn of Africa</a>, more than 3,000 km (1,800 miles) away on the other side of the Indian Ocean. More than 200,000 people were killed, most of them on Sumatra but thousands of others in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Thailand" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Thailand</a>, India, and Sri Lanka and smaller numbers in Malaysia, Myanmar, Bangladesh, Maldives, Somalia, and other locations (<em>see</em> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Indian-Ocean-tsunami-of-2004" class="md-crosslink">Indian Ocean tsunami of 2004</a>).</p><!--[P6]--><p>On March 11, 2011, seafloor displacement resulting from a magnitude-9.0 earthquake in the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Japan-Trench" class="md-crosslink">Japan Trench</a> of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Pacific-Ocean" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Pacific Ocean</a> created a large tsunami that devastated much of the eastern coast of<span id="ref1106592"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Japan-earthquake-and-tsunami-of-2011" class="md-crosslink"> Japan</a>’s main island of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Honshu" class="md-crosslink">Honshu</a>. Waves measuring as much as 10 metres (33 feet) high struck the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/city" class="md-crosslink autoxref">city</a> of <span id="ref1106593"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Sendai-Miyagi-prefecture-Japan" class="md-crosslink">Sendai</a> and other low-lying coastal regions of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Miyagi" class="md-crosslink">Miyagi prefecture</a>, as well as coastal areas in the prefectures of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Iwate" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Iwate</a>, Fukushima, Ibaraki, and Chiba. Several hours later, waves measuring 3.3 to 3.6 metres (11 to 12 feet) were detected in the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Hawaii-state" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Hawaiian Islands</a> chain, and waves measuring about 2.7 metres (9 feet) high washed ashore along the West Coast of the United States (<em>see</em> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Japan-earthquake-and-tsunami-of-2011" class="md-crosslink">Japan earthquake and tsunami of 2011</a>).</p><!--[P7]--><p>Other tsunamis of note include those that followed the spectacular explosive eruption of the <span id="ref821094"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Krakatoa" class="md-crosslink">Krakatoa</a> (Krakatau) volcano on <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/August" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="August">August</a> 26 and 27, 1883, and the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Chile-earthquake-of-1960" class="md-crosslink">Chile earthquake of 1960</a>. A series of blasts from Krakatoa submerged the island of Rakata between Sumatra and Java, created waves as high as 35 metres (115 feet) in many <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/East-Indies" class="md-crosslink autoxref">East Indies</a> localities, and killed more than 36,000 people. The largest earthquake ever recorded (magnitude 9.5) took place in 1960 off the coast of Chile, and it caused a tsunami that killed approximately 2,000 people in Chile, 61 people 15 hours later in Hawaii, and 122 people 22 hours later in Japan.</p><!--[P8]--></section><!--[H4]--><section id="ref299874" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1"><span id="ref1106594"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/tsunami-warning-system" class="md-crosslink">Tsunami warning systems</a></h2><p>The hazards presented by tsunamis have brought many countries in the Pacific <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/basin-landform" class="md-crosslink autoxref">basin</a> to establish tsunami warning systems. A warning may begin with an alert by a geological society that an earthquake large enough to disturb the ocean’s surface (for instance, magnitude 7.0 or higher) has occurred. Meteorological agencies may then report unusual changes in sea level, and then the warning centre may combine this information with data on the depth and features of the ocean floor in order to estimate the path, magnitude, and arrival time of the tsunami. Depending on the distance from the seismic disturbance, government authorities may have several hours’ notice to order the evacuation of coastal areas. The <span id="ref821128"></span>Pacific Tsunami Warning Center, located near <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Honolulu" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Honolulu</a>, Hawaii, was established in 1949, three years after a tsunami generated by a submarine earthquake near the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Aleutian-Islands" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Aleutian Islands</a> struck the island of Hawaii around <span id="ref821127"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Hilo" class="md-crosslink">Hilo</a>, killing more than 170 people. It serves as one of two regional warning centres for the United States—the other is located in Palmer, Alaska—and since 1965 it has also served as the warning centre for 26 countries organized by UNESCO’s Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission into the International Coordination Group for the Tsunami Warning System in the Pacific. Following the disaster of December 2004, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/UNESCO" class="md-crosslink">UNESCO</a> set a goal of establishing similar systems for the Indian Ocean and eventually the entire globe.</p><!--[P9]--><ul class="assemblies medialist" data-type="other"><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" class="h1">Extraterrestrial tsunamis</h2><p>Tsunami waves are not limited to <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Earth" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Earth’s</a> surface. An analysis of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Mars-planet" class="md-crosslink">Martian surface</a> conducted in 2016, which examined the planet’s northern plains by using <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/technology-of-photography" class="md-crosslink">photographs</a> and thermal imagery, revealed evidence of two separate tsunami events. These events are thought to have been caused by <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/comet-astronomy" class="md-crosslink">comet</a> or <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/asteroid" class="md-crosslink">asteroid</a> impacts.</p><!--[P10]--></section><!--[END-OF-CONTENT]--></article><div class="md-learn-more extra-content" data-module="learn-more" data-value="learn-more">        <h2>Learn More <span>in these related Britannica articles:</span></h2>        <ul>        <li class="entry">                <a href="/science/volcano/Mount-Pinatubo-Philippines-1991#ref884163">                    <div class="image-wrapper text-center">                            				<img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/180x300/16/77416-120-6D5A3D41.jpg"  alt="Mount St. Helens volcano, viewed from the south during its eruption on May 18, 1980." />	</div>                    <div class="title"><strong>volcano: Four worst eruptions in history</strong></div>                    <div class="description">A tsunami over 30 metres (100 feet) high followed the explosion and apparent caldera collapse, killing about 36,000 people on the adjacent shores of Java and Sumatra.…</div>                </a>            </li>        <li class="entry">                <a href="/science/volcano/Ash-falls#ref388934">                    <div class="image-wrapper text-center">                            				<img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/180x300/16/77416-120-6D5A3D41.jpg"  alt="Mount St. Helens volcano, viewed from the south during its eruption on May 18, 1980." />	</div>                    <div class="title"><strong>volcano: Avalanches, tsunamis, and mudflows</strong></div>                    <div class="description">…entirely submarine usually generates a tsunami.
